definitions: put out a fire or flame by removing heat or oxygen
bring something to a complete and final end or termination
examples: The firefighters worked tirelessly to extinguish the warehouse blaze
She quickly extinguished the candles before leaving the room
The new policy effectively extinguished all hopes of promotion
The court ruling extinguished their claim to the property

definitions: obtain money or something else from someone through force, threats, or other unfair means
examples: The gang members tried to extort protection money from local businesses
Corrupt officials were caught extorting bribes from construction companies

definitions: remove or take out something from a particular place or position
obtain information or a statement from someone, often with difficulty
obtain a substance from something by using an industrial or chemical process
examples: The dentist carefully extracted the infected tooth yesterday morning
Workers extracted tons of coal from the underground mine
Police finally extracted a confession from the reluctant witness
Researchers extracted valuable data from the ancient manuscripts
The factory extracts essential oils from various aromatic plants
Scientists extract DNA from blood samples for genetic testing

definitions: hand over a person accused or convicted of a crime to the jurisdiction of another state or country
examples: The government agreed to extradite the suspect to face trial
Several countries refuse to extradite individuals who face capital punishment

definitions: extend the application of a method or conclusion to an unknown situation by assuming existing trends will continue
examples: Scientists extrapolate future climate patterns from current weather data
Economists extrapolate market trends from quarterly financial reports

definitions: free someone or something from a constraint or difficulty with effort and care
examples: Rescue workers extricated the driver from the wrecked vehicle
She finally extricated herself from the uncomfortable business partnership

definitions: discharge moisture, smell, or other substance slowly and steadily through pores or small openings
display an emotion or quality strongly and openly in one's manner or appearance
examples: The pine trees exude sticky resin during warm weather
The wound continued to exude pus despite antibiotic treatment
She exudes confidence whenever she enters the boardroom
The old mansion exudes an atmosphere of mystery and decay

definitions: look at or observe someone or something with particular interest or suspicion
consider someone or something as a possibility for a particular purpose or role
examples: Security guards eyed the suspicious package with obvious concern
The cat eyed the bird through the window intently
Several companies are eyeing the vacant property for development
She's been eyeing that promotion for several months now

definitions: look at someone or something directly and closely, often in confrontation or assessment
examples: The two rivals eyeballed each other across the courtroom
The inspector eyeballed the measurements instead of using tools

definitions: construct or manufacture something, especially an industrial product, from prepared components
invent or concoct something, typically a story or excuse, with deceitful intent
examples: The company fabricates specialized metal components for aircraft engines
Workers fabricate steel beams according to precise engineering specifications
The witness fabricated evidence to support his false testimony
She fabricated an elaborate excuse for missing the deadline

definitions: be positioned with the front toward a particular direction or thing
confront and deal with someone or something difficult or unpleasant directly
have a difficult situation or prospect ahead that must be dealt with
examples: The house faces south and receives sunlight all day
Please face the camera when taking your passport photo
She bravely faced her accusers in the courtroom yesterday
The company must face the consequences of its actions
The team faces elimination if they lose tonight's game
Many families face financial hardship during economic downturns

definitions: make an action or process easier or more achievable by providing help or removing obstacles
examples: The new software facilitates communication between remote team members
Government grants facilitate research into renewable energy technologies

definitions: include something as a relevant element when making a calculation or reaching a decision
examples: You need to factor delivery costs into the total price
Economists factor inflation into their long-term financial projections

definitions: gradually lose brightness, color, or strength through exposure or age
gradually grow faint and disappear from sight or hearing
gradually lose strength, vitality, or prominence over time
examples: The curtains have faded from years of sunlight exposure
Dark clothes tend to fade after repeated washing
The music slowly faded as the parade moved away
Her voice faded to a whisper during the speech
His enthusiasm for the project faded after several setbacks
The company's influence has faded considerably in recent years

definitions: be unsuccessful in achieving one's goal or passing a test
cease to work properly or break down under stress or use
neglect to do something expected or required by duty or obligation
examples: Many students fail their driving test on the first attempt
The business failed after only six months of operation
The engine failed halfway through our journey to Boston
Her kidneys failed and she required immediate medical attention
He failed to mention the change in meeting time
The government failed to protect citizens during the crisis

definitions: lose consciousness for a short time because of insufficient blood flow to the brain
examples: She fainted from exhaustion after running the marathon
Several people fainted in the overcrowded concert venue

definitions: pretend to feel or suffer from an illness or emotion to deceive others
make or produce a fraudulent copy or imitation of something valuable
examples: He faked illness to avoid attending the boring meeting
The soccer player faked an injury to waste time
Criminals fake designer handbags and sell them as genuine
Someone faked his signature on several important documents

definitions: move downward typically rapidly and freely without control under gravity
decrease in amount, number, or intensity from a higher level
occur at a specified time or take place as an event
pass into a specified state, condition, or position gradually or suddenly
examples: The apple fell from the tree onto the ground
She fell down the stairs and broke her ankle
Stock prices fell sharply after the earnings announcement
The temperature fell below freezing last night
Christmas falls on a Sunday this year
The responsibility falls to the senior management team
He fell asleep during the long movie presentation
The soldiers fell into formation at dawn

definitions: alter information or evidence fraudulently to mislead or deceive others about facts
examples: The accountant falsified financial records to hide company losses
Someone falsified test results to make the product appear safer

definitions: start to lose strength or momentum and begin to fail or give way
speak in a hesitant or unsteady way showing uncertainty or weakness
examples: The economy began to falter after several interest rate increases
Her determination never faltered despite numerous obstacles
His voice faltered as he delivered the tragic news
She faltered over the difficult words in her speech

definitions: give someone knowledge or understanding of something through instruction or experience
examples: New employees must familiarize themselves with company safety procedures
The teacher familiarized students with basic laboratory equipment

definitions: blow air on something or someone to cool or ventilate
spread out from a central point in a shape resembling a fan
increase the intensity of a feeling or emotion through deliberate action
examples: She fanned herself with a magazine in the hot weather
The waiter fanned the flames to keep the fire burning
The search party fanned out across the entire forest area
The cards were fanned across the table for display
His comments only fanned the flames of the controversy
Media coverage fanned public anger about the scandal

definitions: feel a desire or liking for someone or something, often romantic
imagine something or believe something to be the case without evidence
examples: She's fancied him since they met at university
I really fancy some chocolate ice cream right now
He fancies himself as a talented singer despite evidence otherwise
She fancied she heard footsteps in the empty house

definitions: indulge in daydreaming about something desired but unlikely to happen in reality
examples: She often fantasies about winning the lottery jackpot
Children fantasy about becoming superheroes and saving the world

definitions: perform in a specified way in a particular situation or over a period
examples: The team fared poorly in the championship tournament
Small businesses fared better than expected during the recession

definitions: manage and cultivate land for growing crops or raising animals
send out work to be done by others outside one's company
examples: His family has farmed this land for five generations
They farm organic vegetables for local markets
The company farms out its customer service to overseas contractors
Many businesses farm production to countries with lower costs

definitions: release gas from the digestive system through the rectum with sound or odor
examples: The dog farted loudly during the serious business meeting
Someone farted in the elevator causing everyone discomfort

definitions: make something into a particular form or shape using available materials and skill
examples: The artist fashioned beautiful sculptures from recycled metal pieces
Prisoners fashioned makeshift weapons from everyday items

definitions: close or attach something firmly using a device or tie to prevent opening
examples: Please fasten your seatbelt before the plane takes off
She fastened the necklace around her daughter's neck carefully

definitions: be destined to happen or experience something unavoidable, especially something negative
examples: The project was fated to fail from the beginning
They seemed fated to meet again after many years

definitions: be the male parent of a child through biological or adoptive relationship
be the originator or founder of an idea, movement, or invention
examples: He fathered three children with his first wife
The king fathered many illegitimate children throughout his reign
Einstein fathered the theory of relativity in modern physics
He fathered the environmental movement in our region

definitions: understand something deeply after much thought, especially something complicated or mysterious
examples: Scientists still cannot fathom the mysteries of dark matter
I can't fathom why she made such a reckless decision

definitions: cause someone to feel extremely tired through physical or mental exertion
examples: The long hike through rough terrain fatigued all the climbers
Constant stress and worry fatigued her beyond normal exhaustion

definitions: find error with someone or something and criticize them for inadequacy or mistakes
examples: No one could fault her dedication to the project
Critics faulted the movie for its predictable plot twists

definitions: feel or show approval or preference for someone or something
give unfair preferential treatment to someone at the expense of others
examples: Most voters favor the new healthcare reform proposal
The committee favors candidates with international experience
The teacher clearly favors students who agree with her opinions
The referee was accused of favoring the home team

definitions: mark or designate something as preferred in a list or digital system
examples: She favorited several recipes on the cooking website
Users can favorite posts to save them for later

definitions: feel or show approval or preference for someone or something
give unfair preferential treatment to someone at the expense of others
examples: Most members favour the proposed changes to club rules
The weather favours outdoor activities this weekend
The manager clearly favours employees who stay late
The new law favours large corporations over small businesses

definitions: mark or designate something as preferred in a list or digital system
examples: He favourited the article to read it later
You can favourite locations in the map application

definitions: display exaggerated flattery or affection in order to gain favor or approval
examples: The employees fawned over the new CEO during her visit
Critics accused him of fawning over wealthy donors

definitions: send a document or image electronically using a fax machine over telephone lines
examples: Please fax the signed contract to our office today
She faxed her resume to several potential employers

definitions: disturb or disconcert someone causing them to lose composure or confidence
examples: The hostile crowd didn't faze the experienced speaker
Nothing seems to faze her during high-pressure situations

definitions: be afraid of someone or something as likely to be dangerous or cause pain
be anxious or apprehensive about the possibility of something unwelcome happening
examples: Many children fear the dark until they grow older
The villagers feared the approaching storm would destroy crops
Investors fear another market crash could happen soon
Parents fear for their children's safety in dangerous neighborhoods

definitions: eat and drink abundantly, especially at a special meal or celebration
examples: The wedding guests feasted on delicious food all evening
They feasted their eyes on the beautiful mountain scenery

definitions: cover or line something with feathers for warmth or decoration
turn an oar or propeller blade to reduce resistance when moving
examples: Birds feather their nests with soft down for warmth
The costume designer feathered the dress with exotic plumes
The rower feathered his oars between each powerful stroke
Pilots feather propellers to reduce drag during engine failure

definitions: include someone or something as an important or prominent part
have as a prominent attribute or characteristic aspect of something
examples: The magazine features celebrity interviews every month
Tonight's concert features music from famous Broadway shows
The new smartphone features an improved camera system
The hotel features luxurious spa facilities for guests

definitions: give food to a person or animal to eat for nourishment
supply someone with material or information on a continuous basis
pass something gradually through a confined space or into a machine
examples: She feeds her baby every three hours throughout the day
Farmers feed their cattle twice daily with special grain
Informants regularly feed intelligence to government agencies
The press office feeds stories to journalists before publication
Workers carefully feed wire through the narrow pipe opening
The machine automatically feeds paper into the printer

definitions: be aware of something through physical touch or bodily sensation
experience an emotion or emotional state within oneself
have a particular opinion or belief based on intuition or emotion
produce a particular sensation when touched or experienced physically
examples: I can feel the rough texture of the bark
She felt a sharp pain in her shoulder
He feels happy about his recent promotion at work
They felt disappointed when the concert was cancelled
I feel this decision is wrong for the company
She feels strongly that changes are needed immediately
The fabric feels soft and smooth against your skin
This room feels cold even with heating on

definitions: pretend to be affected by a feeling, state, or injury to deceive others
examples: The defendant feigned mental illness to avoid prosecution
She feigned surprise when they announced her promotion

definitions: make a deceptive or distracting movement to mislead an opponent in combat or sports
examples: The boxer feinted left before delivering a right hook
The fencer feinted high then struck low unexpectedly

definitions: cut down a tree using an axe, saw, or other tool
knock down or cause to fall with force, especially in combat
examples: Loggers felled dozens of trees in the forest yesterday
The storm felled power lines throughout the entire region
The boxer felled his opponent with one powerful punch
A single bullet felled the charging rhinoceros instantly
